Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: 3D Optoelectronic Devices Fabricated via 2-Color Photo-inhibition/initiation Lithography

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective
Traditional photolithography begins with single-photon absorption of patterned light by a photo-initiator to locally expose a resist. In two-color photo-inhibition/initiation (2PII) lithography, these exposed regions are confined by a surrounding pattern of inhibitors generated by one-photon absorption of a second color in a photo-inhibitor. The specific research goal of this proposal is to test the conjecture that the resolution limit of 2PII lithography is enforced by inhibitor diffusion. This will be accomplished by incorporating the 2PII chemistry into thick, solid resists which self-develop index structures in response to 3D direct-write lithography. The resulting solid, photo-patternable materials are foundations for 3D optoelectronic devices in the areas of silicon photonics packaging and high-performance data storage.

Intellectual Merit
The current generations of both semiconductor lithography and optical data storage are at the technological limits of resolution. Although these applications are at opposite ends of the cost spectrum, both industries share an uncertain future in the face of the diffraction limit. By combining 3D resolution superior to existing nonlinear absorption methods with the high sensitivity of photo-resist, the proposed lithography method has the potential to transform optoelectronic micro- and nano-fabrication across a broad spectrum of technologies.

Broader Impact
The research will be integrated into education via the development of an undergraduate optics sequence featuring senior-level design, fabrication and test of 3D optoelectronic and nanophotonic circuitry via software-controlled lithography and self-developing materials. This sequence will be founded on teaching methods featuring design as the core skill of engineering

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

The primary scientific outcome of this work was an understanding, based on new metrology and modeling tools, of the resolution limits of optically-patterned polymer materials used in applications such as lithography, data storage, 3D printing and optical device fabrication.  The central innovation of the project was the use of two laser colors, one of which initiates the polymerization reaction and one which inhibits that reaction.  By overlapping and shaping these foci, we demonstrated resolution a factor of three below the usual diffraction limit on feature size.  

We applied the materials and techniques developed to a number of areas including data storage, three dimensional optical waveguides, 3D gradient-index lenses and holographic optical elements.  Under supplement funding in collaboration with a local business, we extended these applications to 3D bioprinting of "tissue scaffolds" - printed hydrogels containing live muscle or neuron cells for fundamental studies in cellular biology.  

Broader impacts:

The PI developed a new under laboratory course and degree track in optics for electrical engineering students at CU Boulder.  The use of "design" as a fundamental method of teaching engineering was explored in a freshman class in which students design and build their own digital clock, starting with no knowledge of electricity or circuits. 

 


Last Modified: 05/05/2015
Modified by: Robert R Mcleod

The central innovation of the project was the use of two laser colors, one of which initiates the polymerization reaction and one which inhibits that reaction. By overlapping and shaping these foci, we demonstrated resolution a factor of three below the usual diffraction limit on feature size. We applied the materials and techniques developed to a number of areas including data storage, three dimensional optical waveguides, 3D gradient-index lenses and holographic optical elements. Under supplement funding in collaboration with a local business, we extended these applications to 3D bioprinting of "tissue scaffolds" - printed hydrogels containing live muscle or neuron cells for fundamental studies in cellular biology. Broader impacts: The PI developed a new under laboratory course and degree track in optics for electrical engineering students at CU Boulder. The use of "design" as a fundamental method of teaching engineering was explored in a freshman class in which students design and build their own digital clock, starting with no knowledge of electricity or circuits.
